4-5 hours, most time spent reading articles for class or studying for exams.

I honestly don't know, but between the interesting reading and reviewing past lectures I had a steady level of work throughout the semester. Midterms and homework assignments would dominate my study time. I did find all of the course work extremely relevant and interesting so I didn't mind the workload.
3 hours for homework10 hours for examrest: 0 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The topics are interesting, but the slides are a little confusing
I thoroughly enjoyed the course!
Professor was very receptive to what we wanted to learn. Structured lectures in that way. Good combination of biology, epidemiology, behavioral science, policy.
One of the best EMD courses, hands down

Weakness:The class was too rushed and would benefit from being split into a year long course so that topics could be covered in more detail. It would have been helpful in reperation for the exams to have had attendance by Dr. Pettigrew at the review sessions.
The students have a say in what we want to learn. The mix of epi and biology works well. It is a good complement to the Immunology course.
I know that some changes are already going to be made which reflect my opinions regarding improvements.

The contents were very interesting and covers a wide range of infectious diseases. Format is good - lectures and 3 homework assignments.Weakness is that the power points are not always clear and maybe can be improved.
Overall a good class.

Strengths: integrating biology and epidemiology to understanding implications of creating vaccines/implementing programs/policies for infectious diseases. Homeworks were helpful in critiquing and understanding papers and study design implementation. I like the holistic approach to problem solving, including the ethics and the pros and cons of an interventionWeaknesses: afternoon classes means it is harder to stay awake after lunch. Slides were not always clear, but for myself, it takes time to absorb information before being able to ask questions about clarity of the slides. You don't get to touch upon as much about social and behavioral pieces or environmental factors. It would make the class more holistic.Improvements: I think 4 assignments would be better just to get more practice writing about the problems faced with these infectious diseases.

This class was the Dark Horse of my schedule. I was interested but kind of indifferent to the course when it started but within a few weeks really enjoyed going to class and learning about the biology and epidemiology of the many diseases we covered. It became one of my favorite courses this year.

Good to know of the trasmisision pathway of different infectious disease and can understand the status quo and promising future development of diseases.very helpful in keep up with the public health in reality.If ppt can be clearer with some explanation or answers as notes for the question raised , it will be perfect,

I learned great amount of materials in this class. The professor was able to integrate biology and epidemiology very well. Biology part was my least favorite because it requires memorization. I enjoyed examining and solving problems from a broader perspective, and this class definitely help me to do this.

Strengths: very interesting material. I like the format of the course (new concept each lecture).Weaknesses: wish we could cover more diseases. Sometimes feels like we go into great detail on certain mechanisms/pathways, but I feel that the greater overall concepts are more important.I like the idea of merging biology and epidemiology.

Strengths: I loved to combination of the biology/epidemiology with the discussion of policy issues or practical considerations of a given intervention. I will remember much more material from this class than I will from other classes at YSPH!Weaknesses: Jamie Childs' guest lecture.

The strength of this course is that it covers many different topics in an interesting way. Although this is a required course for EMD students, it is an excellent course that I would recommend to other students. There are not many weaknesses other than when we had lecturers other than the professor, it was very difficult to figure out what the key points were for the tests.
It was okay. For people with a microbiology background, it was pretty elementary and not very engaging.

This was an excellent course. In addition to discussing a new infectious agent every lecture, the professor also discussed the epidemiology of the disease and public health significance in today's world, making the lecture material applicable to current circumstances. Although there was a lot of material, having non-cumulative exams was very helpful.

I enjoyed this course, I think it does the best it can to cover diverse topics for each disease system, but obviously it is extremely difficult to cover all topics within a system. I think the important parts of each system was covered. I wish that each system was organized in the same way, briefly going over the molecular level, the natural history, the epidemiology, vaccines and interventions, and then one of these topics will be expanded upon for each.

Great course. I was not an EMD student and still felt like the course was accessible to me. I enjoyed the diversity of the topics and gained a deep knowledge of current infectious agents in our environment. The information learned will be definitely be useful in any future career in public health.
Very good course! Along with the biological knowledge about a pathogen, also learn the public health implications of what we learn in class.
W: Wish I had more time to prepare for exams and wish could have spend at least 2 lectures per topic
Excellent instructor, perfect amount of material to balance out other course loads.

By far one of my favorite classes at YSPH! Biology of IA is an amazing blend of epidemiology and biology of an array of infectious diseases. It provides a solid foundation of basic biology concepts and integrates epidemiology to understand the transmission patterns of disease. The course also does an amazing job of making students critically think about infectious diseases through current research and helps students to critically evaluate public health policies/practices regarding infectious diseases.

Strengths: I think that this class does a good job in terms of providing a nice overview of a number of different pathogens. Moreover, Melinda is very interested in student feedback and leaves several lectures open so that the students in the class can choose what "elective" topics they want to leaner about. This year we learned more about HPV/HCV, bioterrorism agents, SARS, emerging viruses, arboviruses and so forth.I think the best part of this class is that it focuses on bridging science with policy. We learn about the underlying science and biology of various diseases and then using that information are asked to think about and assess the public health implications and ramifications that the biology may impact.
AWESOME should be longer(2 semesters)
On the whole very good but I was hoping for less biology and more epi

The primary weakness is probably the brevity of each topic; I would have really liked to learn about more diseases, and more about more diseases. However, I understand the class is turning into a year-long course, so that is probably a moot point. For the time allowed, I thought the level of detail was excellent; I became much more of an expert in diseases I was previously only vaguely aware of, including means of transmission and mechanisms of disease. The lectures (and slides) were excellent, and I continue to reference them, as many of them have relevance to the work I am doing this summer.I also hate to say it but more homework (gasp!) would probably be beneficial. I did not do very well on the homework assignments until the last one, and I think that was partially because it was unclear to me what was wanted. Homework would be an opportunity, too, to bring in more of the epidemiology side, which at times seemed to be lacking/ignored.

Weaknesses:1)The posted powerpoints could be improved. The slides could include more thorough descriptions of mechanisms, processes, and information about certain studies.2)The course appeared to focus on memorization.

Strengths:The lectures were really informative and organized. The assignments were pretty fair. Studying for the exams took a lot of my time but really helped to fully understand the material.Weaknesses:It was one of the only classes that I stopped doing the readings. There were a lot of articles for the two lectures every week. I was not fully understanding them and realized that anything I needed to know from there would have been covered in lecture. I would have liked to know more about the pathology of the pathogen.

I am glad this course will be divided into two semesters. I think there is too much information trying to be condensed in one semester. I also think there should be weekly assignments. Students would be forced to read for lectures and class. Perhaps the assignments should be due before lecture so students will have a better understanding for lecture and be able to contribute more to the discussion at hand.

This course is the best course offered within EMD. It needs some revamping though. It is so broad and tries to cover too many pathogens in too little time. I think it will be great that it will be offered over the course of two semesters next year. I enjoyed the epidemiology part of the course much more than the details of the biology, which I often found very challenging. If you did not have prior coursework in biology, you will need to spend substantial time trying to figure concepts. However, the biology is important, therefore, I think what is needed is a slower pace.I learned an incredible amount in this class and believe I will use this knowledge on a daily basis.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  nice teacher, but talks too fast
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Very knowledgeable and responsive to questions. Excellent lecturer!
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew is awesome. Great lecturer, fair exams.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Strengths: Dr. Pettigrew is a fantastic instructor! She is always encouraging participation by engaging the students and broadening topics to incorporate the full scope of a public health issues.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  The instructor gives us a say in what we want to learn. She is receptive to feedback. She is good at lecturing and engaging the students both in and out of class.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew is very engaging and had a great mix of biology and epidemiology in each lecture. The switch halfway through worked very well to keep students engaged, in my opinion.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Very knowledgeable and likable by the students. Shows interest in students work and gives a ton of feedback on homework and exams.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is a great speaker and she clearly enjoys lecturing. Her powerpoints could be more organized. We covered lots of infectious agents, but there was definitely a quality-quantity trade off. It was still a good class to get an overview.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda was great and I liked her approach to the purpose and objectives ofthe class. It was hard at times to understand that although we covered a lot of material, that not all of it was necessary for the exams. Some of the material felt repetitive depending on your background and what is covered in other courses if you took it before you took this class. The slides were sometimes confusing, but overall I understand that it can be difficult to put the necessary information on the slides in a way that everyone understands.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is a very knowledgeable and interesting teacher. I learned a lot from her and if she were teaching other EMD courses, they would be courses I would consider taking because I enjoyed her lectures.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Wonderful professor, very engaged and knowledgable
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Very knowlegeble with clever humor. Teach in a clear and logical way.Its really a pleasure to learn from Melinda.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Knowledgeable and witty. not as approachable as seemed, but nice overall.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is an excellent instructor. I like her lecture style--very engaging, approachable to ask questions. She is very knowledgable, and eager to teach. She always answers questions promptly, and will follow up on questions she is unable to answer immediately.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Very clear, very willing to follow up on questions. Great!
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is really great and is a great and interesting lecturer. She is clearly very knowledgeable and knows her stuff.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  She was okay.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Professor Pettigrew was excellent. She knows her material well, is responsive to students' questions, and engages students during the lecture. Her slides can be slightly improved by providing more information in some areas instead of one or two word phrases since students may not be able to catch everything while taking notes.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  She is very knowledgable about a variety of topics, and is engaging in class

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Solid understanding of the course material and was able to lecture to students in a comprehensible manner. Really mastered the topics and powerpoints were well made and detailed. Responsive to student requests and always followed through with answers to questions in class.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Awesome professor! Very knowledgeable, and great instructor.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Excellent instructor. Wonderful ability to answer students' questions and motivate class discussion

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew was an amazing professor! She was truly passionate about her work and wanted students to critically think about infectious diseases not only in theory but how to address them in real world settings. She was most receptive to understanding students' perspectives on how the course was going and wanted to improve it to facilitate students to learn well.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew does a good job of asking for student feedback throughout the semester. She has a wry sense of humor and does a good job of communicating interesting articles to us throughout the semester.Sometimes on exams/homeworks, it was difficult to determine what precisely she wanted us to discuss (i.e. it sometimes seemed that questions were very open-ended but that the work was being graded for very specific answers).
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Incredibly knowledgeable and fair
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Excellent, great teacher, presented the material very well. Speak a little slower next time, please.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  In a lecture hall it is difficult to get class participation (andI admit to being one who did not speak up in class much) but engagement would have brought the class to life in a new way, and prevented the dryness that almost inevitably happens when a lecturer has going through his/her own slides many, many times. Melinda knew her material well, though, and was usually able to field questions about things not on the slides as well. When she was not able to, she addressed the questions promptly at the start of the next class session. I sensed a real dedication to not only teaching but expanding her own knowledge.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Weaknesses:1)Some of the materials that were discussed were quickly discussed. This did not afford enough time to take notes.2)There were a lot of materials presented in one lecture.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew was a great lecturer. She is very conversant in all of the topics. She cared that we understood the material and was very receptive to our questions. She structured the course very well.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew is a wonderful professor. I would recommend working more on the design of the slides. They were confusing to study from.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is a great instructor. I appreciate that her exams were relevant to the take-home messages and not focused on the details we are bound to forget.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Kim and Javier were great TAs overall. Javier might have prepared more for the review sessions. Both TAs could have engaged the class more by uploading relavent journal articles or leading discussions in theforum section of classes v2.Kim's lecture on Borrelia was great.

KimJavierThey both made themselves available to students who needed help. There was inconsistency in grading assignments both across the class and between different assignments. This could be a problem from having two TAs, but the class was double the usual size so it's understandable that two TAs was helpful to the instructor.

I did not have any interactions with the TAs during this course except for during the exam reviews, but I felt that many questions asked by students during the reviews weren't answered in the most complete way.
TAs: Javier Cepeda and Kim Tsao: I only accessed them for review for the finals so I cannot provide much feedback on their TA abilities aside from helping with reviewing for exams.
both TA's did a good job. The review sessions really helped before the tests.
Kim and javier Nice responsible and clear.
mediocre TAsBoth were PhD students. Are they required to take a class in fundamentals of teaching?
The TA's were helpful during review sessions. Otherwise, I did not have any interactions with them.
Kim was a good TA, she was very knowledgable and helpful and she gave a great lecture on Lyme Disease.
Not always knowledgeable about topics covered during review sessions
TA (Kim) was available and very helpful. I really enjoy meeting with her.
The TAs were good- they wanted to help students learn.
Javier and Kim: Both did a good job with the review sessions.Kim's talk on lyme disease was excellent.
JAvier was awful and knew nothing. Reviews were detrimental
I'm not convinced Javier knew the material well. During review sessions he frequently misunderstood students' questions and/or gave answers that were flat-out wrong.

My only interactions with the TAs were during the review sessions, and Leslie Park gave a lecture on Lyme disease. Both she and Javier Cepeda seemed very knowledgable and I have no complaints about either.
My TAs were Kim and Javier. They gave good feedbacks on homework assignments and returned them in a timely manner. They appeared to be accessible to students if students had questions.
Both of the TAs were good. The review sessions helped in studying for the exams. My classes conflicted with office hours which was unfortunate. They were probably under-utilized because of this.
The TAs study sessions were very helpful.
Javier was fantastic, leading session reviews and answering questions via email. We had no interactions with Kim, other than she graded our homework with low grades.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Highly recommend
I would highly recommend this class!

I would highly recommend this course as an introduction to the main infectious diseases studied by public health today. Each lecture covers a new disease in great detail and examines the major public health issues surrounding that disease.
This class is required and it should be taken. There is some overlap with other courses but the material is a core component of the EMD curriculum.

Iwould recommend this class, even for non-EMD students who wish to widen their understanding of human health and disease. I think EMD is restructuring the divisional curriculum, so this class may not be around in the same form as is now.

The course really brings together the biology and epidemiology of infectious diseases in a holistic approach to the prevention and control. I wish there was more application or practice to the problems of these diseases. Perhaps in lieu of a final exam a final project to address a problem would be more rewarding.

One of the most relevant courses you will take as an EMD student. Not only will you learn a lot but as the semester progresses, but EMD seminar will become more interesting because you will have a background on the majority of diseases the guest speakers cover.
Strongly recommend especially for emd students . It will pave the way for your future research and better connected yourself with diffent areas in public health.
yes, very good course for EMD students to take.
Excellent course. Be prepared for a good amount of work, but it is worth it.
This is a required course for EMD students, but it is an enjoyable course and I would recommend it to anyone.
It is just a class on different pathogens. I wouldn't recommend it. It's all things you can self-teach if you're interested.

This is an excellent course for those in EMD or those interested in infectious agents and the epidemiology of these infectious agents. I would recommend this course to other students because you will get a lot of out if regardless of whether you're interested in bacterial, viral, or vector-borne diseases.
This class is going to change, and is required.
Great! I would recommend it to non-EMD students as well, especially thoseinterested in learning about environmental exposures as they related to infectious agents.
Definitely recommend it!
All EMD should take it because it is helpful
Great course.
Highly recommend! If you want a solid foundation in biology and epidemiology of infectious agents, you'll learn a lot!
This is a very valuable class to take because it bridges both the science and policy aspects of public health. It forces one to think as a public health professional should.
Yes

A comprehensive overview about the biology and epidemiology of many important infectious diseases. The title summarizes it pretty well. I would definitely recommend it for anyone interested in infectious diseases!

This is a required course for my division. If I had a choice, I would probably not chose to take this course. This course seemed to place focus on memorization. I would want to take a course that would allow me to learn practical skills in which I can apply when I am working in a professional public health setting.

The class was very helpful in gaining a foundation of infectious disease. I loved the lecture material. Studying for the tests was hard because there was so much that was covered in each section. I would recommend it to anyone in the division.
It is required.
I would definitely recommend to anyone wanting a broad overview of microbial disease.
